Synergistic inhibition of cyclooxygenase-2 expression by vitamin E andaspirin. Abate A, Yang G, Dennery PA, Oberle S, Schroder H ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 230
content: Lesson 2.1: Nutritional manifestoDISCLAIMER:This PDF does not provide medical advice.Nocontent on this PDF file is intended to substitute for professionalmedical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. 2.11 The basicsOur diet determines everything.From the way we think about ourselves and the world, to the way we feel, to theway we look, to our life quality, to our health, to our genetics (there’s an actualepigenetic war going on around us) and the list goes on and on.Food is our fuel and if we give our bodies the wrong kind of fuel all sorts ofproblems will begin sooner or later.Our nutrition is what provides us with the raw materials that our body needs inorder to rebuild itself.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 231
content: So the question is which diet will provide us with the right building blocks and insufficient amounts, and lesson 2 answers exactly that with the bonus that is alsofocused on optimizing one’s testosterone levels since from 1987 the average manin 2021 has 40.8% LESS testosterone.This drop is very dangerous since we are talking about levels less than 500ng/dlwhich lead to depression, anxiety, insomnia, chronic fatigue, man boobs, thyroidproblems, being unmotivated, ED, emotional instability and a huge list of bothphysical and mental problems.So we will both cover the basics of a proper human diet but also add keycomponents that will help you get your testosterone and androgen levels at thetop % of men.But in order to nourish your body like a king you need to optimize gut health first.You can consume the most nutritious foods on the planet but if your gut can notabsorb any of the nutrients, it won’t matter.Everything starts from and depends on the gut.Our gut health affects every biological process that happens inside our bodiesand so, if our gut health becomes dysregulated and suboptimal, every biologicalprocess becomes dysregulated and suboptimal.So focusing on the gut health lesson you saw in lesson 1 will be critical.Now, ee can break a diet down into two parts.Part 1: MacronutrientsMacro means large, so macronutrients are the nutrients that your body needs inlarge amounts (many grams).There are three macronutrients:1)Carbohydrates2)Protein3)FatⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 232
content: Each macronutrient is measured in grams, but the calories per gram of eachmacronutrient isn't the same.Protein and carbohydrates have 4 calories for every gram.Fat has 9 calories for every gram.Every single macronutrient is important.When someone is deficient insaturatedfats for example,his cells break downand function poorly. Cells need saturated fats, not only for fuel but also forstructural components and to participate in metabolic pathways. We need qualityfood sources of fat because fat is a carrier of the important fat soluble vitaminsA,D,E and K. Without the proper absorption of these vitamins, our health willbegin to deteriorate since they are important for many functions of the body suchas the function of the thyroid and the iron homeostasis.Each of the fat soluble vitamins has an estrogen lowering and thus testosteroneenhancing effect.Saturated fats are a critical substance for optimal testosterone production, as weneed them in order to begin producing testosterone in the first place (see lesson1 Leydig cell).When we are talking about fats, we are not talking about high inflammatory fatsand unstable when exposed to heat such as vegetable oils but saturated fatswhich are anti-inflammatory, stable when exposed to heat, lower endotoxins andsupport steroid hormone production.Avoid unsaturated fats and consume saturated fats in order for your cells to beable to rebuild properly. ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 233
content: So quality fat sources are:1)The yolks of free range eggs3)Quality grass fed organic/raw dairy3)Coconut oil4)EVOO (not for cooking)5)Grass fed butter and ghee6)Grass fed tallow7)Avocados8)Blackseed oil (cold pressed)9)Organic palm kernel oil10)Bone marrowNote:The oils with the lowest linoleic acid percentagewhich makes them thebest oils to cook your meals in are:ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 234
content: 1) Grass fed butter/ghee2) Grass fed tallow3) Coconut oilMoving on to carbohydrates.Carbohydrates are organic compounds that consist of carbon, oxygen andhydrogen as you can see in the following graph. There are three main types of carbohydrates:1)Starches2)Fiber3)SugarsWe mostly like fructose, some specific types of fiber and very very few types ofstarch since they are the most pro metabolic.Carbohydrates are our body's main source of energy: They help fuel our brain,kidneys, heart muscles, and central nervous system.Carbs are broken down by the body into glucose whichis used as fuel by yourbody’s cells, tissues, and organs. Glucose is also extremely important for thebrain, which can’t easily use other fuel sources like fat or protein for energy.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 235
content: A carbohydrate-deficient diet may cause headaches, fatigue, weakness, difficultyconcentrating, nausea, thyroid issues, metabolic issues, hormonal issues (eventhough the last three are kind of one and the same), vitamin and mineraldeficiencies which is one of the reasons people who take part in keto andcarnivore diets for years have tremendously aged skin and decreased skinelasticity.Carbs are probably the best macronutrient that can be pseudo characterized asan “antioxidant” since fats and protein produce less CO2 which acts as apowerful antioxidant than carbs.Some cells in the body can only run on carbs.So carbsare the preferred fuel ofthe body and without them it will raise stress hormones and thus metabolicproblems.Last but not least, fructose, which will be mentioned in the micronutrient densefoods, has been proven to lower SHBG levels and allow for more freetestosterone in the bloodstream.Quality carb sources are:1)Raw honey2)Raw dairy3)Any seasonal and organic fruit4)Berries5)Kiwis6)Orange and grapefruit juice with no pulp7)Sprouted rice cooked in bone broth8)Extremely ripe bananas and mangos9)Some sweet potatoes10)Pumpkin11)Squash12)Some sprouted spelt bread once in a whileⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 236
content: 13)Some maple syrupNote: carbs should be consumed with protein and (some) fat and you should golow-ish carb (0.7 grams per pound) for 2-8 weeks if you struggle with issues suchas candida while focusing on optimizing glucose metabolism as demonstrated inlesson 1.Last but not least, protein.Protein is composed of amino acids, which are organic compounds made ofcarbon, nitrogen, hydrogen and oxygen (or sulfur).Amino acids are the building blocks of proteins and proteins are the buildingblocks of muscle. Proteins also regulate the body’s processes that help itmaintain fluid balance. Albumin and globulin for example are proteins in our blood that help maintain ourbody’s fluid balance by attracting and retaining water.You need to provide your body with quality animal protein since it is constantlybreaking it down during the day and in order to produce pro metabolic hormones.Protein also is also the most thermogenic (“converts better to heat”) of the threemacronutrients and needed for the stimulation of stomach acid and promoteoptimal digestion.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 237
content: A chronic protein deficient diet is very dangerous and will lead to the breakdownof your body.Having experimented with myself and clients over the years besides readingpapers, the ideal amount of protein somone could consume every day, is 2-2.5grams per kg of bodyweight.If you go over this sooner or later you will face problems with amonia most likely,and if you go lower than this stress hormones will rise.Note 1: When we are referring to protein we are referring to sources that have ahigh protein bioavailability aka animal products which are rich in crucial vitamins,minerals and aminos that plants are not.Things such as zinc, copper, carnitine, vitamin A, choline, B vitamins, CLA andcreatine that animal products are rich in, are all crucial for a healthy body.Plants have their (crucial) place in someone's diet, but a) the right plants andb)prepared the right way.Note 2: When it comes to protein we need the proper ratio of the aminos such astyrosine, glycine, taurine, proline, alanine, and tyrosine with the aminos such asmethionine, cysteine and tryptophan. In order for this to happen stick toproteinsources such as:1)Free range grass-finished meats if possible2)Free range organic eggs3)Raw dairy4)Bone marrow5)Low heavy metal seafood6)Organ meats7)Lamb8)Some grounded muscle meats once in a while with bone broth rice on the side9)Some shrimp10)OystersSo here’s a simple reminder in the form of a food pyramid.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 238
content: Now, each one of these nutrients has a different digestion and absorption time.For example, fats can take up to 3 times more time to be digested than carbs.So typically, a pre workout meal if you are interested in performance, shouldprimarily include carbs and protein.A ratio of 50% carbs, 30-40% protein and 10-20% fat, seems to be ideal for a preworkout meal.When it comes to macronutrient ratios, a thing that many unfortunately dismiss asa “bro myth” but will actually help many people that are familiar withmacronutrient ratios is eating based on your somatotype (metabolic typing).There are three somatotypes (which are obviously not a bro myth).1) EctomorphEctomorphs are thin, small boned and usually they can not gain weight easily.This somatotype should be more carb based macronutrient wise.The ideal macronutrient ratio seems to be: 40-50% carbs, 30-40% protein and20% fat.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 239
content: 2) EndomorphEndomorphs have larger bone structure and they carry by default muscle but alsofat. They can put on fat as easily as they put on muscle but it’s almost impossiblefor them to get lean.Endomorphs a lot of times get mistaken as such due to metabolic damage andthyroid issues. So before you characterize yourself as an endomorph apply whatyou read on chapter 1 for at least 12 weeks.If you’re an endomorph, the best macronutrient ratio seems to be: 40-50%protein, 20-30% carbs and 20-30% fat.3) MesomorphMesomorphs have medium size bone structure and can put on weight fairly easilyif they focus on a decent caloric surplus such as 400-500calories. These peopleare natural muscle gainers and can see progress with almost any type ofprogram. It’s not uncommon for these people to put on muscle on basicbodyweight splits.The ideal macronutrient ratio for this type seems to be: 30-40% carbs, 30-40%protein and 20-30% fat.Jack of all trades macronutrient split.Having experimented with many macronutrient ratios, the majority of people wholive busy lives but also want to have good and intense training sessions, respondbest to a 40% protein, 30% carbs and 30% fats breakfast and lunch, a 40-50%carbs, 30% protein and 20-30% fats for dinner and as we said a 50% carbs,30-40% protein and 10-20% fat pre and post workout meals.This would be a good place to start if you are a beginner and interested inmacronutrient ratios in order to improve your performance.Part 2: MicronutrientsMicronutrients are vitamins and minerals needed by the body in very smallamounts (mg and μg) . However a deficiency in any of them can cause severeⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 240
content: health problems since they perform a range of functions, including enabling thebody to produce enzymes and hormones.Micronutrients > Macronutrients.The fuel you give your body matters. You might be able to give it crap for fuel fora few months but sooner or later it will catch up to you.A calorie is not a calorie. Nutrition matters. It’s not a coincidence that the mostfilling foods are also the most nutritious foods. Try getting full by eating potatochips…… ain’t happening. You can eat 2000kcal of chips and not get full at allbecause there’s zero nutrition in there. On the other hand , try not getting full byeating 2000kcal of meat and fruits. You will get full.Some say that you’re getting full because of the volume of food you consume.Not the case.Try having 2000 kcal of rice cakes , yeah you’ll get full…..for 30 minutes.Your body is not dump , if you provide it with proper fuel , you’ll be able to cross along distance and if you don't , you'll be able to cross only a short distance.There are 25 key vitamins and minerals. So let’s see which ones are they andwhere we should get them from.2.12 The 25 key vitamins, minerals and their bioavailable sourcesFirst of all, vitamins are organic substances that are generally classified as eitherfat soluble or water soluble.Fat soluble vitamins such as: vitamin A, vitamin D, vitamin E and vitamin Kdissolve in fat and tend to accumulate in the body. They also need to beconsumed with a meal that has saturated fats (ex coconut oil, EVOO) in order tobe absorbed properly.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 241
content: Water soluble vitamins such as: vitamin C and the B-complex vitamins mustdissolve in water before they can be absorbed by the body, and therefore cannotbe stored.Any water-soluble vitamins unused by the body are primarily lost through urine.Minerals are inorganic elements present in soil and water, which are absorbed byplants or consumed by animals and include things such as: calcium, magnesium,potassium, zinc, copper and iodine.Now let’s see these vitamins and minerals one by one.1)Vitamin A (Retinol) Vitamin A is an essential micronutrient meaning that our bodies cannotmanufacture it and therefore it has to be included in our diet.Vitamin A from food is stored in the liver until required by the body and isessential for many physiological processes, including maintaining the integrityand function of all surface tissues such as the skin, the lining of the respiratorytract, the gut, the bladder, the inner ear and the eye.Vitamin A supports the daily replacement of skin cells and ensures that tissuessuch as the conjunctiva are able to produce mucus and provide a barrier toinfection.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 242
content: Vitamin A is also essential for vision under conditions of poor lighting, formaintaining a healthy immune system, for growth and development and forreproduction.The best sources of vitamin A (retinol) are:1)Beef, duck, chicken, lamb and turkey liver2)Organs3)Raw cheese4)Egg yolks5)Grass fed butter and ghee6)ClamsVitamin A should not be supplemented due to its toxicity and the classicsymptoms that someone might experience a deficiency in vitamin A areextremely dry skin (vitamin C, E and K2 also play an important role on this one)and eyes and loss of night vision.2)Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) Thiamine helps the body's cells change carbohydrates into energy as we saw inlesson 1.Thiamine also plays a role in muscle contraction and conduction of nerve signalsand is essential for the metabolism of pyruvate.Thiamine helps prevent complications in the nervous system, brain, muscles,heart, stomach, intestines and is also involved in the flow of electrolytes into andout of muscle and nerve cells.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 243
content: The best food sources of vitamin B1 sources:1)Brewer’s yeast2)Organic pork cooked in some coconut oil3)Sprouted rice cooked in bone broth4)Spirulina5)Some organic coffee6)OrgansThiamine can also be supplemented and most of the thiamine supplements are ofdecent quality.The basic rules for thiamine supplementation is to always supplement it with ameal that has some carbohydrates, avoid supplementing thiamine for more than4-6 weeks straight and it is best to consume thiamine up until 4 P.M in order forsomeone not to face any sleeping problems.But thiamine will always be a better option for an energy boost than coffee later inthe day.The typical signs of not only a thiamine but a B vitamin deficiency in general arechronic fatigue and symptoms of neurological diseases such as memory loss buteven under performing mentally and ADD like symptoms. ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 244
content: 3)Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) Riboflavin is important for body growth, it helps in red blood cell production andaids in the release of energy from proteins.Riboflavin is crucial for converting tryptophan to niacin, helping the adrenalsproduce hormones and maintaining the mucous membranes in the digestivesystem.We need to consume vitamin B2 daily, because the body can only store smallamounts and its supplies go down rapidly.The best food sources of vitamin B2 are:1)Spirulina2)Beef3)Brewer’s yeast4)Raw dairy5)Mushrooms6)Egg yolks7)AvocadosMost B2 supplements should be avoided except spirulina and brewer's yeastsupplements which are extremely effective for replenishing B2 levels andrelatively safe.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 245
content: 4)Vitamin B3 (Niacin) Niacin is one of the eight B vitamins, and it’s also called vitamin B3.There are two main chemical forms of niacin:1)Nicotinic acid2)Niacinamide (sometimes called nicotinamide)The key role of niacin in our body is to synthesize the coenzymes nicotinamideadenine dinucleotide (NAD) and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate(NADP), which are involved in over 400 biochemical reactions in your bodymainly related to obtaining energy from the food we eat (see lesson 1).The best food sources of vitamin B3 are:1)Organic pork cooked in some coconut oil2)Chicken soup3)Turkey with a side of bone broth4)Skirt steak5)MushroomsAs we saw, vitamin B3 can be supplemented but only if a few key componentsare in check first as we saw in lesson 1.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 246
content: 5)Vitamin B5 (Pantothenic acid) Vitamin B5, also called pantothenic acid, is necessary for making blood cells andas with all B vitamins it helps us convert the food we eat into energy.Vitamin B5 is needed for:●healthy skin, hair, and eyes●proper functioning of the nervous system and liver●healthy digestive tract●making red blood cells, which carry oxygen throughout the body●making sex and stress-related hormones in the adrenal glandsThe best sources of vitamin B5 are:1)Egg yolks2)Chicken liver3)Beef kidney4)Sprouted rice with mushrooms5)Raw dairySupplementing B5 can be tricky and it's best to be avoided.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 247
content: 6)Vitamin B6 Vitamin B6 or pyridoxine, is a water-soluble vitamin found naturally in manyfoods, as well as added to foods and supplements.Pyridoxal 5’ phosphate (PLP) is the active coenzyme form and most commonmeasure of B6 blood levels in the body.PLP is a coenzyme that assists more than 100 enzymes to perform variousfunctions, including the breakdown of proteins, carbohydrates, and fats;maintaining normal levels of homocysteine (since high levels can cause heartproblems), supporting immune function and brain health.Vitamin B6 plays an important role in mood regulation.This is partly because this vitamin is necessary for creating neurotransmittersincluding serotonin, dopamine and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA).Vitamin B6 may also play a role in decreasing high blood levels of the amino acidhomocysteine, which have been linked to depression and other psychiatricissues.The best sources of vitamin B6 are:-Beef liver (and other organs)-FishⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 248
content: -PoultryVitamin B6 should not be supplemented and avoided in any artificial form (most, ifnot all, energy drinks have an artificial form of vitamin B6).7)Vitamin B7 (Biotin) Biotin improves the texture of the skin by preventing oxidative damage, isessential in improving the cognitive functioning of the brain by repairing the braincells, is extremely important for our vision and is helpful for people suffering fromkidney problems.As with all B vitamins, biotin is a coenzyme for carboxylase enzymes that areinvolved in:●synthesizing, or creating, fatty acids●synthesizing the amino acids isoleucine and valine●gluconeogenesis, or generating glucoseThe best sources of vitamin B7 are:-Beef liver-Egg yolks-Pork (if organic)ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 249
content: -Salmon roe every once in a whileBiotin can be supplemented if needed relative safely just make sure that youhave enough magnesium, copper and zinc in your system.8)Vitamin B8 (Inositol) Although inositol is referred to as vitamin B8, it is not a vitamin but a sugar thatplays a structural role in the body as a major component of cell membranes andis necessary for blood sugar control.In addition, it affects the regulation of serotonin and dopamine.Inositol has many potential benefits and is usually used for psychological issues(depression, anxiety) and metabolic problems.Now, unless someone is deficient in inositol, the above benefits all spring fromthe improvement of glucose metabolism since a dysregulated glucosemetabolism will lead to issues such as mood swings and panic attacks.The best sources of vitamin B8 are:-Beef-Citrus fruit juices with no pulp such as orange juice or grapefruit juiceⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 250
content: Just make sure to not combine the two.Inositol can be supplemented pretty safely if someone has enough choline in hissystem. So if you are going to take inositol make sure to have some eggs in theday.Note since we are talking about supplements: Do NOT start taking one trillionsupplements to improve your health and check the supplement guide in order tounderstand better how to use supplements.9) Vitamin B9 (folic acid) Vitamin B9 or folic acid is crucial for proper brain function, plays an important rolein mental and emotional health, aids in the production of DNA and RNA, thebody's genetic material, it helps to control blood levels of the amino acidhomocysteine along with B6 and B12, can prevent and even reverse age relatedhearing loss and macular degeneration, can protect the development of manyforms of cancer and the list keeps going and ends with the fact that a B9deficiency can cause birth defects and even miscarriages.The best sources of vitamin B9 are:-Beef liver-Organic asparagus and spinach cooked in grass fed butter or ghee (the cookingin animal fats is crucial in order to lower the antinutrient content).ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 251
content: 9)Vitamin B12 Vitamin B12 is needed to form red blood cells, DNA and it helps in the functionand development of brain and nerve cells.Vitamin B12 binds to the protein in the foods we eat and the hydrochloric acidand enzymes in the stomach unbind vitamin B12 into its free form by freeing itfrom haptocorrin.From there, vitamin B12 combines with a protein called intrinsic factor so that itcan be absorbed further down in the small intestine.Vitamin B12 also functions as a cofactor for two enzymes, methionine synthaseand L-methylmalonyl-CoA mutase.Methionine synthase catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to the essentialamino acid methionine.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 252
content: Methionine is required for the formation of S-adenosylmethionine, a methyl donor(crucial for testosterone as you will see) for almost 100 different substrates,including DNA, RNA, proteins, and lipids.The best sources of vitamin B12 are:-Beef liver-Beef-Clams-Sardines-Raw dairy10) Beta carotene Beta carotene is a precursor of vitamin A and like all carotenoids, it is anantioxidant.Many studies have suggested that those who consume at least fourdailyservings of beta carotene rich fruits and/or vegetables have a lower risk ofdeveloping cancer, lung issues, heart disease and experiencing cognitive decline.Also, the most neglected nutrient for thyroid health is probably beta carotene.The best beta carotene sources:1)PumpkinⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 253
content: 2)Squash3)Peaches4)Carrots5)Apricots6)Cantaloupe7)Mangos8)Sweet potatoes9)Plums10)Grapefruit juice (no pulp)11) Boron Boron is a trace mineral that helps our bodies metabolize vitamins and minerals,has a key role in bone health and brain health and affects estrogen, SHBG, freeand total testosterone levels.Boron can also extend the half life of vitamin D, help the adrenals, improvemuscle coordination, muscle glycogen, sleep and remove sodium fluoride.The best dietary sources of boron are:-Prunes-Raisins-AvocadosⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 254
content: Just look at the ingredients in prunes and raisins since most of themunfortunately are laced with inderior fats such as sunflower and canola oils.Supplemental boron is even recommended every once in a while these days dueto the amount of sodium fluoride most people have consumed over the years, notenough bioavailable calcium and bad soil health.The typical dose of 3-6 mg is good enough and i do not suggest going higher.12) Vitamin C From protecting our cells against oxidative stress, maintaining healthy skin, bloodvessels, iron homeostasis, heart, improved nitric oxide function, glucosemetabolism, blood volume regulation, bones and cartilage all the way tosteroidogenesis, fighting allergies, reducing cortisol, improving sleep, preventingcognitive decline and supporting the thyroid gland, vitamin C is an extremelyimportant nutrient.The best dietary sources of vitamin C:1)Acerola cherry juice (no pulp)2)Blackberries3)Pomegranate juice (no pulp)4)Kiwis5)Oranges juice (no pulp)6)Grapefruit juice (no pulp)ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 255
content: 7)Strawberries8)Raspberries9)PineappleYou can supplement vitamin C but as we said make sure to consume it with ameal that has sodium in it and wash it down with an acidic beverage preferablesome of the mentioned juices.If you are going to supplement with vitamin C supplement with a dose as low as250 mg and do not increase it if there’s no need for it but always favorpomegranate and acerola cherry juice (no pulp) over synthetic vitamin C.13) Calcium Calcium is a mineral needed for bone and teeth formation, nerve function,regulating heartbeat and helping muscles to contract.About 99% of the body’s calcium is stored in bones and the remaining 1% isfound in blood, muscle, and other tissues.The body gets the calcium it needs in two ways. One is by eating foods thatcontain calcium and the other is by drawing from calcium in the body.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 256
content: If one does not eat enough calcium-containing foods, the body will removecalcium from bones.Ideally, the calcium that is “borrowed” from the bones will be replaced at a laterpoint.But this doesn’t always happen, and can’t always be accomplished just by eatingmore calcium if vitamin K2 and D levels are not optimal.The best sources of calcium are:-Raw dairy-Bone broth/marrow-Eggshells14) Choline (Vitamin J or B4) Choline plays an important part in many processes in your body, including cellstructure (make fats that support the structural integrity of cell membranes), braindevelopment, cell messaging, fat metabolism (without enough choline cholesterolwill buildup in the liver instead of being used), DNA synthesis, a healthy nervoussystem (choline is required in order for the neurotransmitter acetylcholine to beⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 257
content: made which is involved in muscle movement and regulating heartbeat amongother things) and healthy leptin levels.The best sources of choline are:-Egg yolks (any type (chicken, fish and so on)).-Liver-Red meatEven though not necessary, if you ever supplement with choline stick toCDP-choline and alpha-GPC.15) Copper Copper is an essential trace mineral found in higher concentrations in organssuch as theliver, kidneys, brain and heart.The mitochondria depend on copper for energy metabolism and copper plays akey role in functions within the body such as: red blood cell production, ironabsorption, the regulation of heart rate and blood pressure, the development andmaintenance of connective tissue, bones and organs, immune systemmaintenance and activation, brain development, a healthy supply of white bloodcells and takes part in oxygen metabolism.Copperis absorbed partially in the stomach where the highly acidic environment frees theⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 258
content: bound copper ions from partially digested foods. However, the largest portion ofingested copper passes into the duodenum and ileum, which are the major sitesof absorption so a high fraction of copper is soluble in the intestinal tract and inorder for copper to be properly absorbed and utilized one must focus on healinghis gut as well.The best sources of copper are:-Organ meats-Shellfish-Organic cacao16) Vitamin D Vitamin D is technically a hormone and is best created when UV light from thesun hits your skin (it is produced endogenously when ultraviolet (UV) rays fromsunlight strike the skin and trigger vitamin D synthesis).Vitamin D along vitamin K2 are the hidden keys for bone health.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 259
content: Vitamin D promotes calcium absorption in the gut and maintains adequate serumcalcium and phosphate concentrations to enable normal bone mineralization andto prevent hypocalcemic tetany besides being needed for bone growth and boneremodeling by osteoblasts and osteoclasts.Vitamin D has other roles in the body, including reduction of inflammation as wellas modulation of such processes as cell growth, neuromuscular and immunefunction and glucose metabolism as we saw.Vitamin D plays a key role in preventing autoimmune diseases, muscle waste,reverse steroid driven hair loss, glucose metabolism, steroidogenesis, calciumabsorption.17) Vitamin E Vitamin E is a lipid-soluble component in the cell antioxidant defense system andis exclusively obtained from the diet but vitamin E is heavily dependent on vitaminC, vitamin B3, beta carotene, selenium and glutathione.So applying what you’ve read so far and optimizing glutathione function (lesson1) will be critical in order for the body to be able to utilize vitamin E properly.Vitamin E is one of the most effective antioxidants we have in our disposal andmaking sure to provide enough dietary vitamin E will greatly improve everyaspect of one’s health.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 260
content: The best sources of vitamin E are:-Palm kernel oil-EVOO-Egg yolks-LiverMost, if not all, vitamin E supplements are toxic and should be avoided.18) Vitamin K Vitamin K refers to agroup (K1 and K2)of fat solublevitamins which are foundthroughout the body including the liver, brain, heart, pancreas and bones andthus protecting each one of these.The first (K1) is called phylloquinone and found in green leafy vegetables likecollard greens, kale, and spinach.The second (K2), menaquinones, are found in some animal and fermented foodssuch as natto.Vitamin K helps to make various proteins that are needed for blood clotting(*) andthe building of bones(**).ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 261
content: (*)Prothrombin for example is a vitamin K-dependent protein directly involved withblood clotting.(**)Osteocalcin is a protein that requires vitamin K to produce healthy bonetissue.The best sources of vitamin K are:-Natto-Raw dairy-Egg yolks-Cheeses-Spinach cooked in animal fatsVitamin K can be supplemented if it is in a liquid form with an EVOO base.19) Manganese Manganese is a trace mineral and is found mostly in bones, the liver, kidneys,and pancreas.It helps the body form connective tissue, bones, blood clotting factors, sexhormones, plays a role in fat and carbohydrate metabolism, calcium absorption,blood sugar regulation, supports fertility, is a component of the antioxidantenzyme superoxide dismutase which helps fight free radicals and is necessaryfor normal brain and nerve function.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 262
content: But you do not need that much manganese so the weekly oysters and occasionalorganic cacao and maple syrup will take care of any needs.Manganese supplements usually are not recommended due to the fact that mostbrands use toxic fillers.20) Magnesium Magnesium is the fourth most abundant mineral in the human body and it’ssomething most people are deficient in.During digestion, three primary digestive enzymes turn food into nutrients thatcan be absorbed and assimilated by the body and magnesium plays a role innumerous enzyme systems throughout the body.Magnesium directs excessive calcium outside the cell, promoting relaxation in thestressed areas.Magnesium also lowers SHBG levels and therefore it can increase freetestosterone.Magnesium assists more than 300 enzymes to carry out various chemicalreactions in the body such as building proteins, strong bones,oxidativephosphorylation, glycolysis, blood pressure, muscle and nerve functions.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 263
content: Magnesium also acts as an electrical conductor that contracts muscles andmakes the heart beat steadily.More than half of the magnesium in our body is stored in bones, and theremaining in various tissues throughout the body.Magnesium also plays a role in the active transport of calcium and potassiumions across cell membranes.The best sources of magnesium are:-Mineral water-Cacao-Swimming in the clean ocean-Some magnesium supplements that are not filled with artificial sweeteners andtoxic food additives.Just make sure to use different forms since every form of magnesium tends to goto a specific tissue (for example glycinate has a preference for muscle tissue) soit is in fact better to use different chelates as well.Start with magnesium glycinate and perhaps citrate if you are going to use asupplemental form. ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 264
content: 21) Phosphorus Before you even worry about phosphorus, make sure that you get enoughcalcium in your diet.Having too much phosphorus in the body is actually more common than havingtoo little.Next to calcium, phosphorus is the most abundant mineral in the body and these2 work closely together.Phosphorus helps filter out waste in the kidneys and plays an essential role inhow the body stores and uses energy.Phosphorus is needed for the growth, maintenance, and repair of all tissues andcells, and for the production of the genetic building blocks, DNA and RNA.Phosphorus is also needed to help balance and use other vitamins and minerals,including vitamin D, iodine, magnesium, and zinc.The best source of phosphorus is raw milk. ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 265
content: 22) Potassium Potassium is an essential mineral that is needed by all tissues in the body.Its main role in the body is to help maintain normal levels of fluidinsideourcells(*).Sodium, its counterpart that we will see in a second, maintains normal fluid levelsoutsideof cells(**).Potassium also helps muscles to contract and supports normal blood pressure.Potassium is the third most abundant mineral in the body.(*)Potassium is the main electrolyte in the ICF, and it determines the amount ofwater inside the cells.(**)Sodium is the main electrolyte in the ECF, and it determines the amount ofwater outside the cells.So a typical sign of a potassium:sodium imbalance is having to pee almostimmediately after consuming a food high in potassium.The best sources of potassium are:-Avocados-BananasⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 266
content: -Winter squash-PotatoesMost potassium supplements should be avoided.23) Selenium We briefly mentioned selenium’s importance in lesson 1 so to wrap things up,selenium is a trace mineral which is an essential component of various enzymesand proteins, called selenoproteins that help to make DNA and protect againstcell damage and infections.These proteins are also involved in reproduction and the metabolism of thyroidhormones as we saw.Most selenium in the body is stored in muscle tissue, although the thyroid glandholds the highest concentration of selenium due to various selenoproteins thatassist with thyroid function.The best sources of selenium are:-Shellfish-Fin fish-Organic brazil nuts-Beef-TurkeyⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 267
content: -ChickenJust make sure to have just one of the above foods in a small portion every dayand your selenium needs will be covered.Most selenium supplements are toxic.24) Sodium Sodium is one of the body's electrolytes (minerals that the body needs inrelatively large amounts and carry an electric charge when dissolved in bodyfluids such as blood).Most of the body’s sodium is located in blood and in the fluid around cells.The human body requires sodium to conduct nerve impulses, contract and relaxmuscles, and maintain the proper balance of water and minerals.Without enough sodium in your diet you will experience adrenal fatigue, gutproblems, insomnia and ED (these are the first symptoms).Obviously do not go all the way to consuming 20 grams of sodium a day. ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 268
content: Just do not drink too much water (if you have to go to the bathroom every houryou are consuming too much water and destroying your stomach acid) and saltyour foods since the best source of sodium is of course sea salt.Avoid himalayan salt due to iron fortification.25) Zinc Last but not least, zinc.Zinc is a trace mineral necessary for almost 100 enzymes to carry out vitalchemical reactions that play a key role in the creation of DNA, growth of cells,building proteins, healing damaged tissue and supporting a healthyimmunesystem.Because it helps cells to grow and multiply, adequate zinc is required duringtimes of rapid growth, such as childhood, adolescence and pregnancy.Zinc is also absolutely necessary for a healthy gut and is the primary factor in ourability to recycle vitamin C.The best sources of zinc are:-Shellfish-BeefⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 269
content: Zinc supplements are best to be avoided since they will always lead to some kindof zinc:copper imbalance and do not take a zinc supplement that has copper in itsince copper in its artificial forms is toxic.When we talked about macronutrients, at the end we briefly talked aboutmacronutrient splits and timing.Now is there a thing such as a micronutrient split and timing?Yes there is.You need different types of nutrients in different amounts during different times ofthe day.(There are many meal plans presented in this product and all of them are basedon micronutrient timing and after you’re done reading this program a couple oftimes you will have understood the philosophy behind it).List of the most micronutrient dense rich foods ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 270
content: 1)FruitFruits are high in vitamins, antioxidants and minerals but most importantly, fruitsare high fructose.Carbohydrates are the most efficient source of energy we humans have accessto and fruits produce more CO2 than fats and protein in general and CO2 is agood thing since it decreases oxidative damage.We need carbs and fruits are one of the best carb sources that exist (raw dairyand raw honey are the other ones).The only thing we need to mention though is that despite the fact that fruitsshould be an important part of your diet, they should very, VERY rarely be eatenby themselves as we mentioned.Here’s a list of recommended fruits (but always favor what’s in season and local) :-Any kind of berry-Kiwis (for 0 blood types)-Pineapple (for A blood types)-Cherries-Peaches (for 0 blood types)-Apricots (for A blood types)-Watermelon-MelonⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 271
content: -Pomegranate juice with no pulp-Pumpkin-Figs-Oranges for juice (no pulp)-Passion fruit-Mangos-Grapefruits for juice (no pulp)2)Organ meatsThere’s a reason organ meats have become so popular the last few years. Theyare some of the most micronutrient dense foods that exist.They probably are the most micronutrient dense food after raw dairy and thefoods highest in vitamin A.A vitamin that is super important for your metabolism, thyroid and to maintain aproper balance of : magnesium, zinc and copper in the body.The only “bad” thing about organ meats is that since most people today have ahigh enough iron content in their body, they should be consumed with somecarrots, mushrooms or carrots in order to prevent iron overload and also not becombined with foods high on vitamin C.Recommended organ meats are :-Beef liverⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 272
content: -Beef heart-Beef kidney-Chicken liverBut please try to also consume organ meats only from quality animals sinceotherwise yes, the organs of the animals instead of healing you, can poison you.The simplest test for this that exists is that if the organ meats have a strongmetallic taste, do not eat them.3)Seafood and shellfishGreat sources for: vitamin B6 (something a lot of depressed people are deficientin and neglected even though it is crucial for testosterone production), Niacin,B12, Zinc, Copper, Phosphorus, essential fatty acids and some Vitamin E.Recommended seafood and shellfish are:-Sardines-Cod-Shrimp-Oysters4)EggsAn egg has every single nutrient a little chicken needs to be born. So yeah, theyare nutrient dense. Eggs are great sources of : Vitamin A, Choline, Potassium,Folate (and B vitamins).ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 273
content: Obviously, eggs are important too because your body needs enough cholesterolin order to produceeveryimportant hormone.5)Brewer’s yeastBrewer’s yeast contains small organisms (microflora) that help maintain theproper functioning of the digestive tract.Brewer’s yeast is a rich source of: Thiamine (B1), Riboflavin (B2) (which a lot ofpeople are deficient in), Folic acid (B9), Biotin (B7), Niacin (B3), Selenium,Potassium, Zinc and Magnesium.6)Raw dairyThere’s a reason raw dairy is illegal and it’s not because the government isconcerned with your health. Raw dairy heals issues you don’t even realize youhad.Any kind of raw dairy you can get your hands on is recommended.7)CollagenCollagen is the most abundant component of the extracellular matrix and is theprotein that determines your skin physiology. Collagen is way more importantthan we might think, especially as we age since collagen decreases.Collagen use can help : tendon injuries, joint pain, gut issues, wrinkle reductionand the improvement of skin hydration.2.13 What else to avoid1) GMOs and hybridized grainsA Genetically Modified Organism (GMO) is something whose genetic material(DNA) has been interfered with in a way that does not occur naturally by matingor natural breeding.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 274
content: Well, DNA is a complex structure and altering it in any way can create newconsequences and structures in the cell’s composition, as well as its relationshipwith other cells.For example,when potatoes were genetically engineerednot to show bruising(*). A side effect of this engineering was an increase in the potato's aminoadipicacid content. An acid that has been shown to increase the risk of diabetes.(*)The potato still bruises, it's just that the bruises don't show up because themelanin gene has been suppressed.Genetic engineering also alters the nutritional value of foods which resulted in theGE food containing the same amount of calories with significantly less nutrition.Which is obviously not good since “empty” calories basically deplete you ofnutrients and can damage your mitochondria.Americans have been eating GM food for over 20 years and over 80% of theirprocessed food contains GMOs.GMOs are one of the main reasons why every generation is sicker than the lastone. It is very sad today that avoiding GMOs seems almost impossible. GMOs donot harm only our health, but our unborn kids' health and the environment.GMOs in reality are an attempt for big food corporations to take total control ofour food system (with the help of George W. Bush).We have known for decades that GMOs severely damage the immune system inrats. In one study the Russian national academy of sciences reported that morethan half the babies from mother rats fed GM soy died within three weeks, weresmaller (a lot, smaller) and could not reproduce. Also mice that were fed GMtriticale (a grain hybrid) showed enlarged lymph nodes and when goat’s were fedGM soy their milk contained very very small amounts of proteins instead of thetypical numbers (from 3-5 gr per 100ml usually depending on the goat).ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 275
content: Since GMOs were introduced into the food supply the rate of chronic healthconditions among children in the US increased from 12.8% (in 1994) to 26.6% (in2006).(Especially for things like asthma, behavioral and learning problems).Remember the mention we did on glyphosate? The majority of GM crops are“roundup ready” (herbicide resistant) which is glyphosate for the most part, whichdamages the ecosystems and encourages the development of “super weeds”(weeds that are extremely resistant to glyphosate).GMOs are one of the reasons allergies are so common nowadays. GE (geneticengineering) can transfer allergens from one food to another. For example, whena gene from brazil nuts were engineered into soybeans, people allergic to brazilnuts had the same allergy reactions when eating this batch of soy products asthey would when eating brazil nuts. So GE can “transfer” the allergy you have ona specific food to another food that you consider safe.GE can also cause new allergic responses since well, you’re consumingsomething that hasneverexisted and your body doesnot know what to do withit. GM soy for example can develop 27% higher levels of trypsin-inhibitor (anallergen).What can you do to avoid GMOs.#1 Buy local seasonal fruit.#2 Buy organic if you can afford it.#3 Look for Non-GMO seal#4 Avoid crops where GE is extremely common ( corn, soybeans, canola,cottonseed, sugar (cane sugar is typically GMO free though), modern grains,bananas and papayas and unfortunately most dairy (*) since they’relikely to beGMO unless they are labeled as No rBGH, rBST, or artificial hormones).ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 276
content: (*) The term most dairy does not include raw dairy, a few specific types of grassfed cheeses and milk from farms that you know what the animals are fed.Note: These things so far may seem too much if you try to implement them.Hybridised grainsA lot of people today suffer from brain fog which is alleviated for most of themafter cutting out grains and most starch sources.In modern agriculture, grains are probably the number 2 (soy is probably thenumber 1) thing that is sprayed with enormous amounts of herbicides such asglyphosate. A herbicide linked to cancer and which also leads to environmentalcatastrophes by destroying bee populations.Glyphosate was introduced to the marketplace in 1974 but data on its use is onlyavailable since 1990.Monsanto has genetically modified foods so that they are resistant to glyphosate,a herbicide Monsanto sells, resulting in a dramatic increase in the use ofglyphosate. The study points out that research has shown that "glyphosatedisrupts the ability of animals, including humans, to detoxify xenobiotics.This means that exposure to the chemicals in food and the environment, such asendocrine disrupting chemicals and carcinogens, could be causing levels ofdamage that would not occur if the body were able to detoxify them.Modern grains destroy people’s guts and brains. There is zero doubt about it.99.999% of people who go gluten free experience positive health benefits. Alsomost of the modern grains have been through excessive hybridization which endsup making gluten very very hard to digest compared to pre hybridized grains suchas einkorn for example. That’s the whole problem with gluten. That the glutenthat’s coming from modern wheat has nothing to do with the gluten we’ve beeneating for thousands of years.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 277
content: Grains are also high in mycotoxins such as ochratoxin anddeoxynivalenol. Theeffects of mycotoxins on human health can be both acute and chronic, provokingproblems such as liver cancer and respiratory problems. Mycotoxins causepesturbation in the gut, particularly in the intestinal epithelial. Most of the reportedeffects of mycotoxins on human health are negative both short term and longterm.Grains are also high in phytic acid which impairs the body's absorption of iron,zinc, and calcium and can contribute to a lot of mineral deficiencies over time.Most people today are already deficient in a lot of important minerals. Glyphosatealso holds on things like manganese, magnesium and minerals in general to thepoint of starving the plant itself. So a) the nutrient content of the plant is low tobegin with and b) the phytic acid lowers your body’s storage of nutrients (unlessthe plant is cooked in animal fats but still it only works in a sufficient level onlywith green leafy greens).Bread has its place in the human diet (after you’ve addressed issues like candidaand SIBO) because of the production of nicotinamide riboside and that’s why Isuggest eating bread from organic einkorn or spelt sprouted flour once in a while(once every 2-3 weeks).2) Food additivesFood additives are chemicals added to foods to keep them fresh or to enhancetheir color, flavor and texture. They can include things like:-Anti-caking agents (they stop ingredients from becoming lumpy).-Antioxidants (they prevent foods from oxidizing/going rancid).-Artificial sweeteners (increase the sweetness).-Emulsifiers (stop fats from clotting together).-Food acids (they maintain the right acid level).-Colors (they enhance/add color).-Humectants (they keep foods moist).ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 278
content: -Flavors and flavor enhancers.-Foaming agents (they maintain uniform aeration of gasses in foods).-Preservatives (they stop microbes from multiplying and spoiling the food).-Thickeners and vegetable gums (they enhance texture and consistency).-Stabilizers and firming agents (they maintain even food dispersion).-Raising agents (they increase the volume of food through the use of gasses).-Bulking agents (they increase the volume of food without major changes to itsavailable energy).And many other things (MSG etc)Some food additives can be safe in moderation but there are big problems withthings like : artificial sweeteners (worse than GMO sugar), preservatives (food issupposed to rot within a few days), colors, thickeners , bulking agents andvegetable gums.The more unnatural a food becomes the more unhealthy it is. Yet the fitnessindustry has brainwashed people into poisoning themselves with this stuffbecause “they’re low in calories and fill you up”.Food additives harm mostly children. For example the artificial colorings “FD&Cyellow no.5 and no.6” cause allergic reactions very often in children and arelinked with hyperactivity. Also unfortunately, parents often feed their kids trashdeli meats which have sodium nitrates in them most of the time which whenheated and combined with one’s stomach acid produces nitrosamines which arelinked with an increase of pancreatic and colorectal cancer. You must also avoidlike the plague in case you have kids foods that include sulfur dioxide, potassiumbisulfite and sodium sulfite. Basically just feed your kids normal food and checkthe labels of your foods since big food corporations add synthetic crap toeverything these days. Even milk.Now artificial sweeteners such as aspartame, sucralose , saccharin, stevia etcare destroying our gut (*), our liver (**)and lead to wild food cravings down theⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 279
content: road. They use artificial sweeteners in everything these days even if it has hugeamounts of sugar in it.(*) Artificial sweeteners pass through the human GI tract without being digestedso they come in direct contact with microbes in the colon resulting in makingpreviously healthy gut bacteria to become diseased and invade the gut wall(anyone who has any gut/intestinal issues should stop consuming artificialsweeteners immediately). Artificial sweeteners can also cause glucoseintolerance way faster than GMO sugar a lot of times.And anyone who might struggle with cancer should immediately stop consumingartificial sweeteners since they have been shown to increase the size ofcancerous tumors. Researchers have called aspartame “a multi potentcarcinogenic compound” and have pointed to the many dangers of artificialsweeteners.Artificial sweeteners in some cases can also trigger irritable bowel syndrome andcrohn’s disease in susceptible patients.(**) Studies have shown that increased consumption of artificial sweeteners(especially in soft drinks) leads to lipid (fat) accumulation in the liver, fibrosis, anddegeneration of the liver.3)LegumesSome sprouted legumes have their place in someone’s diet when he is extremelyhealthy. Most of us are not extremely healthy and consuming legumes will lead toa lot of problems from digestive distress to improper absorption of minerals.(Unsprouted) legumes combine the worst characteristics of grains, nuts andvegetables and should be avoided if you have health issues.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 280
content: “But legumes are high in nutrients” someone may say. Well, you can’t talk aboutnutrients of a food without checking the antinutrients that it contains.Legumes usually contain large amounts of lectins, phytic acid, phytoestrogens,cyanogenic glucosides (which interfere with iodine absorption and metabolism) ,isoflavones , and soluble fiber which in large doses can harm the liver. Legumesalso are high in protease inhibitors.Proteases are enzymes that break down proteins. So Protease Inhibitors aremolecules that stop proteases from doing their job.Also no matter what you do you should avoid canned legumes since they usuallycontain mega doses of BPA.For this reason it is best for most people to take a break from (unsprouted)legumes for 1-2 months before reintroducing sprouted legumes once every 15days.4) Nut “milks”/Dairy “alternatives”Just as calling seed oils, “oils” is wrong, so is calling nut milks, “milks”.These are not milks. Milk comes only from animals.How are nut “milks” even made? Most of them are made by blending up the nutswith water letting them sit for a while and then straining the mixture to remove thesolids and add things like the seed oils we mentioned, artificial colorings andsweeteners.Well the problem with this is that you are basically drinking poison.You are megadosing on antinutrients, herbicides and pesticides.This is the only thing that you are getting out of these nuts by blending them withwater and straining the mixture.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 281
content: Almonds for example are extremely high in oxalates and a lot of poor kidsdeveloped kidney and bladder problems from drinking almond milk. Even babiesare fed this stuff nowadays.Almond milk also somehow both indirectly and directly destroys bee populationsand contributes to environmental damage. It is best to avoid nut milks since theypoison you without providing anything beneficial.When it comes to meat alternatives, you shouldn’t eat phytoestrogen, glyphosate,GMO, food additive pumped foods that even starving dogs won’t eat (true story)and provide zero nutrition but tons of antinutrients.Beyond meat’s burgers had an endocrine disrupting effect even more than somebirth control pills. Please avoid.2.14 The most neglected aspect in every diet: waterMost of our bodies contain water. Water is a carrier, well the problem is what itcarries.We mentioned 12 commonly found substances that you can find in water inchapter 1.Here will just put a friendly reminder that the water you consume will play a keyrole in shaping your gut microbiota, hydration levels and thus blood volumeregulation, heart and artery health.Always favor spring water and what i recommend clients do is get a water filterand a glass bottle that they will fill up with the addition of some (a pinch) of seasalt.This way you will not have to worry about chemicals that are put in the water orBPA leaking in it if you leave your bottle in the sun.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 282
content: Using distilled water and remineralizing is not recommended since most distilledwater is actually filtered dirt water*2.15 Glycemic indexThe glycemic index in our context, is a system of assigning a number to eachcarbohydrate containing food according to how much it affects blood sugar whichis what makes it a great tool since you do not need to spike your blood sugar thesame with each meal.After getting in tune with your body, you will have a good understanding of what agood baseline for glucose levels feels in your body and you will use the MED inorder to spike insulin just enough to bring it back to a good level with each mealand not on overdrive.You will basically know what food you need in each scenario aka what kind of aninsulin spike you actually need (fast, medium, slow).There are 3 GI rating:1)Low: 55 or lessThese are carbohydrates that break down slowly during digestion, release bloodsugar gradually into the bloodstream and include things such as: berries,cherries, pears, strawberries, kiwis and (raw) carrots.2)Medium: 56-69These are carbohydrates that break down moderately during digestion, releaseblood sugar moderately into the bloodstream and include things such as: (ripe)bananas, (ripe) mangos, pineapple, figs, raisins, beets and grapes.3)High: 70+These are carbohydrates that break down quickly during digestion, release bloodsugar rapidly into the bloodstream and include things such as: watermelon, datesand mash potato.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 283
content: 2.16 Amino acidsWhen proteins are digested, amino acids are left. The human body uses aminoacids to make proteins to help the body:First we have aliphatic side-chain aminos which are:●Glycine●Alanine●Valine●Leucine●Isoleucine●ProlineThe we have polar neutral side-chains aminos which are:●Serine●ThreonineAmide side-chain aminos include:●Asparagine●GlutamineSulfur containing side-chain aminos include:●Cysteine●MethionineAromatic side-chains aminos include:●Aspartate●GlutamateCationic side-chain aminos include:●Histidine●Lysine●ArginineBeta and gamma amino acids include:ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 284
content: ●Beta alanine●CarnosineEach one of these aminos is crucial for our health (since they are also necessaryfor the production of amino acid derivatives) but what’s more crucial is the ratio ofthem since an imbalance in any of these can cause serious health problems.In order to prevent this from happening, one should try to mix different types ofanimal proteins such as red meat, shrimp, some white fish, shellfish,eggs andoccasionally poultry but also try to consume one of the following every day whichwill lead to the proper amino acid balance.●Bone broth/Bone broth rice●Bone marrow●GelatinAmino acid supplements it’s better to be avoided* ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

content: 2.17 Micronutrient balanced meal examples Meal 1Ingredients-1-2 teaspoons of extra virgin coconut oil-5-8 free range eggs-Sea salt-Smoked paprika-5 mushrooms-1 teaspoon of ghee-½ an avocado-3-6 olives-Handful of spinachⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 286
content: Throw 1-2 teaspoons of coconut oil in a pan. Crack 3-4 whole eggs and the eggwhites in there. Add sea salt , pepper and cayenne and wait until the whites arecooked but the yolks remain raw.Put the eggs on a plate and throw in the pan as many mushrooms as you want.Wait for 1-4 minutes and then throw 1 teaspoon of ghee with some spinach. Ifyou’re a big guy put aside ½ an avocado with some olives.Cooking the spinach in ghee or butter is crucial in order to increase vitamin Kabsorption while messing up it’s antinutrients that are what have given spinachsuch a bad rap.Note:Say no to omelets.Micronutrients this meal contains-Vitamin A-Vitamin A precursor-Beta carotene-Vitamin B1-Vitamin B2-Vitamin B3-Vitamin B5-Vitamin B6-Biotin-Folate-Vitamin B12-Magnesium-Potassium-Vitamin K-Manganese-Copper-CholineⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 287
content: -ZincMeal 2(Pre/Post workout meal option or snack)Ingredients-200gr of full fat plain goat’s yogurt in a bowl.-3 teaspoons of raw honey-A handful of blueberries ( or mixed berries)-1-2 kiwis or slices of pineapple-½ a teaspoon of cinnamon-1 teaspoon of quality cacao or a couple of pieces of 85%+cacao chocolate (check the ingredients to make sure there aren’t any seed oils in there).Simply mix all of them in a big enough bowl.Butwhy goat’s dairy?Well it’s way , way easier to digest.Less allergy risk.Less chances to be polluted.Goat’s are feeded way less hormones than cows.It’s also higher in short and medium chain fatty acids.Contains less lactose.It contains more B6 , potassium , calcium and vitamin A than cow’s milk.Now we use cinnamon and berries to regulate the insulin response from this mealsince berries can decrease the insulin response of a meal by even up to 26 %and cinnamon has shown a reduction ( of 21 %) in fasting glucose, as well as ininsulin resistance when consumed in doses up to 1 gram.We also use berries and cacao to regulate the cholesterol response from meal 1.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 288
content: Since both of these combined can cause even a 40% reduction in oxidized LDLlevels.Micronutrients this meal contains-Calcium-Phosphorus-Potassium-Chloride-Zinc-Iron-Copper-Selenium-Vitamin B1-Vitamin B2-Vitamin B3-Vitamin B5-Vitamin B6-Biotin-Folate-Vitamin B12-Vitamin C-Vitamin K1Note : The vitamins and minerals that are not mentioned in the meals but thefoods in the meal contain them, are not mentioned because they either are notbioavailable or are in a very small dose ( example : 5 mg of vitamin c) .The only supplement I would consider taking with this meal would be niacin.Meal 3ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

content: Ingredients-250-300gr of ground beef with sea salt-½ teaspoon of turmeric ( unless your iron levels are low )-½ teaspoon of paprika-Dash of black pepper-Dash of oregano-Dash of cayenne-2 tomatoes-6-8 olives-2-3 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil-2 teaspoons of ghee ( or tallow)-1 carrot-As much lettuce as you want-1 beetrootMix the beef with the spices mentioned and make 4-5 patties out of it.Place a nice cast iron pan over high heat and throw in there some ghee since ithas an even higher smoking point than tallow ( if you can not handle dairy at all,switch the ghee with tallow).Place the patties and cook every side for 2-3 minutes.Grab a big bowl. Chop the vegetables , add sea salt and drizzle them with extravirgin olive oil.Done.Note : You can also put on the salad any other non starchy vegetable you candigest such as carrots ( especially if you have problems with iron overload) ,lettuce etc.Micronutrients this meal contains-IronⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 290
content: -Zinc-Vitamin C-Vitamin E-Folate-Vitamin K1-Beta carotene-Lycopene-Selenium-Riboflavin-Vitamin B3-Vitamin B6-Vitamin B5-Vitamin B12Meal 4Ingredients-200-300gr of chicken breast-1 cup of rice-⅓-½ teaspoon of cayenne-½-1 teaspoon of smoked paprika-½-1teaspoon of sea salt-Dash of black pepper-1-2 teaspoons of ghee-6-8 olives-1 cup of bone brothⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 291
content: -Handful of blueberries-2 kiwisHere’s how you make bone broth the easy way in case you missed it in lesson 1.Get 2-3kg of marrow bones.Put the bones in a large stock pot and cover them with cold water. Bring them toboil and simmer for 15 minutes in high heat. Then drain and rinse the bones withwater.Preheat the oven to 200 celsius and place the bones in a roasting pan. Roast for35-45 minutes. Transfer the bones back to the stockpot. (Make sure to wash yourpots after the bones are blanched and drained.) Fill the pot with water until thebones are fully submerged. Cover the pots and bring to a boil. Reduce heat tolow and simmer for at least 6-12 hours ( add more water if needed). Once thebones have simmered and your broth is ready, you will need to strain the broththrough a strainer. Add as much sea salt as you want and you’re done. Store thebone broth inside sealed jars in the freezer.Having bone broth rice instead of regular rice has a huge ROI.You’re adding gelatine , glycine and glutamine in a meal out of nothing.In order to make the bone broth rice , simply add 1 cup of bone broth , 1 cup offiltered water and 1 cup of rice in a pot on medium/low heat and stir until the riceis cooked.Now take the chicken breast and throw on it all of the spices mentioned.Now bake the chicken in the oven with some ghee and a few drops of water.Place the bone broth rice on a plate , the chicken with some olives on top andplace next to this 2 kiwis and a handful of blueberries.The supplement I would take with this meal would be magnesium and I wouldconsider aspirin with glycine if I was beginning my health journey after years ofabusing my body through seed oil , gluten and alcohol consumption.Micronutrients this meal contains-Vitamin C-ManganeseⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 292
content: -Quercetin-Myricetin-Potassium-Kiwellin-Kissper-Pholate-Phosphorus-Lutein-MagnesiumMeal 5Ingredients-2 scoops of quality casein-1 teaspoon of cacao-1-3 teaspoons of honey-1 teaspoon of cinnamon-1-2 servings of any non citrus fruit (banana for example).If you can not digest whey or casein, switch it for 30gr worth of protein from eggwhites and 1 whole egg ( you don’t need more than 12 eggs per week unlessyou’re severely malnourished).Why casein and not whey?Because it’s far superior when properly made.Casein is considered a “scam” in the fitness industry a lot of times.It isn’t.It’s just harder to produce than whey.Way harder.That’s why a quality casein protein is more expensive.The slow release of amino acids from casein are mostly used to create hormonesand remove toxins from the body.ⒸHelios_Movement LLC

title: Page 293

content: 4. NiacinNiacin is another B vitamin which is called vitamin B3.Niacin is used from the body in order to break down fats and protein, convertingfood into energy and cellular metabolism.Niacin works with enzymes to metabolize food calories and absorb nutrientswhich are spread throughout the organs and muscles of the body, providing themwith continual energy.It is water-soluble, so our bodies do not store it, which also means that your bodycan excrete excess amounts of the vitamin through urine if they are not needed.Niacin has an essential role in cell signaling and DNA repair.Niacin also boosts hydration in the skin and a cell's ability to retain water and itmay help prevent certain types of skin cancer as well, as studies found thatparticipants who took niacin twice a day had reduced rates of nonmelanoma skincancer compared to the control group.The brain also requires niacin (NAD and NADP) to get energy and functionproperly.Important note:Start with a very small dose (50-100mg),do not supplement withnon flush niacin, do not exceed 200 mg, always take niacin with food and do notsupplement with niacin for more than 3-4 weeks straight.Best times to consume niacin?In the morning with breakfast as you saw in the previous part of the course.5.
